wesm commented on a change in pull request #2887: ARROW-3614: [R] Support for timestamps
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2887#discussion_r232452085
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/tests/testthat/test-Array.R
 ##########
 @@ -230,13 +230,13 @@ test_that("array supports Date (ARROW-3340)", {
 test_that("array supports POSIXct (ARROW-3340)", {
   times <- lubridate::ymd_hms("2018-10-07 19:04:05") + 1:10
   a <- array(times)
-  expect_equal(a$type(), date64())
+  expect_equal(a$type(), timestamp(unit = TimeUnit$NANO))
 
 Review comment:
   Is this right? Why not use the native unit of `time`?

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

javierluraschi commented on a change in pull request #2887: ARROW-3614: [R] Support for timestamps
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2887#discussion_r232473618
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/tests/testthat/test-Array.R
 ##########
 @@ -230,13 +230,13 @@ test_that("array supports Date (ARROW-3340)", {
 test_that("array supports POSIXct (ARROW-3340)", {
   times <- lubridate::ymd_hms("2018-10-07 19:04:05") + 1:10
   a <- array(times)
-  expect_equal(a$type(), date64())
+  expect_equal(a$type(), timestamp(unit = TimeUnit$NANO))
 
 Review comment:
   Since `timestamp()` does not define a default: https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/R/R6.R#L319. Or, maybe I'm misunderstanding what you mean by native?

wesm commented on a change in pull request #2887: ARROW-3614: [R] Support for timestamps
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2887#discussion_r232495879
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/tests/testthat/test-Array.R
 ##########
 @@ -230,13 +230,13 @@ test_that("array supports Date (ARROW-3340)", {
 test_that("array supports POSIXct (ARROW-3340)", {
   times <- lubridate::ymd_hms("2018-10-07 19:04:05") + 1:10
   a <- array(times)
-  expect_equal(a$type(), date64())
+  expect_equal(a$type(), timestamp(unit = TimeUnit$NANO))
 
 Review comment:
   Why are you converting the representation of `times` to nanoseconds? I thought POSIXct was represented internally as seconds

romainfrancois commented on issue #2887: ARROW-3614: [R] Support for timestamps
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2887#issuecomment-437966636
 
 
   ```r
   > str(Sys.time() - Sys.time())
    'difftime' num -9.05990600585938e-06
    - attr(*, "units")= chr "secs"
   ```
   
   So you have 9e-6 seconds difference
   
   

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

users@infra.apache.org

javierluraschi commented on issue #2887: ARROW-3614: [R] Support for timestamps
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2887#issuecomment-437967287
 
 
   Something else to consider... Spark only supports microsecond timestamps, so someone needs to make a conversion somewhere, see [arrow/ArrowUtils.scala](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/8c2edf46d0f89e5ec54968218d89f30a3f8190bc/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/arrow/ArrowUtils.scala#L73).
   
   I can send a PR to Spark; however, Spark from [spark/pull/22913](https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/22913), Spark is trying to minimize conversions in Java, which are probably slower than in Rcpp. So I would still need a way to convert to microseconds somewhere.
